title: Problem Overview
content:
**Erdős Problem #1127: Decomposing ℝⁿ into Sets with Distinct Distances**

**Question:** Can ℝⁿ be decomposed into countably many sets where all pairwise distances within each set are distinct?

**Answer:** YES, assuming the Continuum Hypothesis.

**Status: SOLVED** with conditions (CH required)
mathContext: The problem connects geometry (distance) to set theory (Continuum Hypothesis) in a deep way.

title: Distinct Distances Property
content:
**HasDistinctDistances S:**

A set S has the distinct distances property if every two distinct pairs of points have different distances.

Formally: If {p₁, p₂} ≠ {p₃, p₄} are pairs in S, then dist(p₁, p₂) ≠ dist(p₃, p₄).

title: Countable Decomposition
content:
**CountableDecomposition X P:**

A set X admits a countable decomposition with property P if X can be written as a disjoint union ⋃ᵢ Sᵢ where each Sᵢ satisfies P.

The key question: can this be done with P = HasDistinctDistances?

title: The Continuum Hypothesis
content:
**ContinuumHypothesis:**

The assertion that |ℝ| = ℵ₁, i.e., the cardinality of the reals equals the first uncountable cardinal.

This is independent of ZFC - neither provable nor disprovable from standard axioms.

title: ℚ-Linear Independence
content:
**IsQLinearlyIndependent S:**

A set S ⊆ ℝ is ℚ-linearly independent if no finite nontrivial linear combination over ℚ equals zero.

Equivalently: the elements of S are 'algebraically unrelated' over the rationals.
mathContext: For any distinct x₁,...,xₙ ∈ S and rationals a₁,...,aₙ, if Σaᵢxᵢ = 0 then all aᵢ = 0.

title: Erdős-Kakutani Theorem (1943)
content:
**erdos_kakutani_equivalence:**

The Continuum Hypothesis is EQUIVALENT to the statement:
'ℝ can be written as a countable union of ℚ-linearly independent sets.'

This is a remarkable characterization of CH in terms of linear algebra!
mathContext: CH ↔ ∃(S : ℕ → Set ℝ), (∀i, IsQLinearlyIndependent (S i)) ∧ (⋃i, S i) = univ

title: Davies' Theorem (1972)
content:
**davies_theorem:**

Assuming CH, ℝ² can be decomposed into countably many sets with distinct pairwise distances.

This extended Erdős-Kakutani from dimension 1 to dimension 2.

title: Kunen's Theorem (1987)
content:
**kunen_theorem:**

Assuming CH, ℝⁿ can be decomposed into countably many sets with distinct pairwise distances, for ALL dimensions n.

This completely solves the problem under CH.

title: Erdős-Hajnal Necessity
content:
**erdos_hajnal_necessity:**

If CH is FALSE, then for any finite partition of ℝ, there exist 4 points in one piece determining at most 4 distinct distances (instead of the required 6).

This shows CH is NECESSARY for the decomposition to work.
mathContext: ¬CH → finite partitions fail the distinct distances property

title: Main Result
content:
**erdos_1127:**

CH → ∀n, Erdos1127Question' n

Assuming the Continuum Hypothesis, ℝⁿ can be decomposed into countably many sets with distinct pairwise distances, for every dimension n.

This follows immediately from Kunen's theorem.
